questions.question: A 45 y/o male patient is admitted to the ICU following a major road traffic accident, resulting in multiple fractures and abdominal injuries. The patient is currently unable to take oral nutrition. He is expected to require enteral feeding for more than 3 weeks. Imaging studies reveal delayed gastric emptying and significant gastric distension. What is the most appropriate route for enteral nutrition in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Feeding jejunostomy Explanation: This trauma patient has delayed gastric emptying with significant gastric distension and requires long-term enteral nutrition for more than 3 weeks . Therefore, feeding jejunostomy is the most appropriate route as it bypasses the stomach, thereby reducing the risk of complications such as aspiration and further gastric distension. Types of Artificial nutritional supports: Nasogastric tube (Option A) & ryles tube (Option B): Indicated when the duration of the feeding requirement is less than 3 weeks and the patient having good gastric emptying. Feeding gastrostomy (Option C): Indicated when the duration of the feeding requirement is more than 3 weeks and the patient having good gastric emptying.

questions.question: A 38-year-old male involved in a motor vehicle accident has been in the ICU for several days with multiple injuries including head and abdominal trauma. The ICU team is considering starting enteral feeding. Which of the following findings would most likely contraindicate the initiation of enteral nutrition in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Proximal small intestinal fistula Explanantion: Enteral feeding should be avoided in proximal small intestinal fistula as it can lead to increased fistula output, worsening fluid and electrolyte imbalances. Enteral Nutrition: Indications Contraindications Protein-energy malnutrition with inadequate oral intake Small bowel obstruction or ileus Dysphagia except for liquids Severe diarrhea Major trauma or surgery when returning to dietary intake is prolonged Proximal small intestinal fistula (Option C) Inflammatory bowel disease (Option A ruled out) Severe Pancreatitis ( the food particles stimulate the release of pancreatic enzymes, ultimately worsening the symptoms.) Distal low-output enterocutaneous fistula (Option B ruled out) GI bleed Complications of enteral nutrition Category Complications Tube-Related Complications Malposition Displacement Blockage Leakage Erosion of skin and mucosa Gastrointestinal Complications (due to high osmotic load) Diarrhea Abdominal cramps Aspiration Constipation (Option D ruled out) Metabolic Complications Dyselectrolytemia (increased risk) Deficiency of vitamins, minerals, and trace elements Infective Complications Endogenous Exogenous Reference: Bailey and love Short practice of surgery, ed.28, page 336, 337, 338 SRBâ€™s Manual of Surgery 6e, pg no 96, 97

questions.question: A 45-year-old male recovering from gastrointestinal surgery is on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Initially, he was receiving a 2-in-1 TPN formulation. Due to ongoing nutritional needs, the medical team switches him to a 3-in-1 TPN formulation. Which component is newly included in the 3-in-1 formulation that was not in the 2-in-1?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lipids Explanation: In a 3-in-1 TPN, lipids are included along with dextrose and amino acids, which are present in 2-in-1 TPN. TPN Formulations: 3 in 1 formulation 2 in 1 formulation Solutions with lipids (Option C) Solutions without lipids 60/20/20 60% by dextrose 20% by amino acids 20% by fat. 75/25 75% by dextrose (OPTION B ruled out) 25% by amino acids (OPTION A ruled out) No lipids used (OPTION C) Fiber is absent in both the formulations (Option D ruled out) Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, page 338.

questions.question: A 72-year-old male with severe pancreatitis is initiated on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to his inability to tolerate enteral feeding. Shortly after the central venous catheter is inserted, he complains of sudden onset shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. On examination, his breath sounds are decreased on the same side of the catheter insertion. What is the most likely complication that has occurred?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pneumothorax Explanation: Sudden onset of symptoms after central venous catheter insertion for TPN with decreased breath sounds on the same side of insertion site are pointing towards pneumothorax. Complications of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) Line Insertion Complications Pneumothorax (most dangerous) Misplacement of catheter Line-Related Complications Sepsis (most common) Thrombosis (more common with long-term catheter use) Electrolyte imbalances (e.g., refeeding syndrome) Metabolic Complications Blood sugar derangements (hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia) Liver dysfunction Metabolic bone disease Vitamin deficiencies Reference: Bailey and love Short practice of surgery, edition 28, page 339.

questions.question: A 45 year old male severely malnourished patient with a history of chronic alcoholism and recent weight loss is admitted in the hospital. After stabilization, he is started on a high-calorie enteral feeding regimen to address his nutritional deficiencies. Within 48 hours of initiating feeding, he begins to have muscle weakness, difficulty in breathing and is confused. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities in the blood is least likely to be associated with his current condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hypernatremia Explanation: In this scenario, the likely diagnosis is refeeding Syndrome , which can cause shifts in electrolytes as the body transitions from a catabolic to an anabolic state. Hence, hypernatremia is not commonly associated with refeeding syndrome. Refeeding syndrome: One of the most significant metabolic complications of both parenteral and enteral feeding. This occurs in the first days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished. The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with EITHER One or more of the following: (OR) Two or more of the following: BMI <16 kg/m 2 BMI <18.5 kg/m 2 Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months. Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days. Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics. Mechanism of Refeeding Syndrome: Electrolyte abnormalities: Hypophosphatemia, (Option A ruled out) Hypomagnesemia, (Option C ruled out) Hypokalemia, (Option B ruled out) Hypocalcemia Lead to arrhythmia, confusion, and respiratory failure, ultimately leading to death. Management: Matching the intake with requirements. Avoid overfeeding Calorie delivery should be increased slowly Vitamin administration (Thiamine): Given before feeding. Electrolyte abnormalities should be corrected

questions.question: A 30-year-old male undergoes abdominal surgery, and the surgeon plans to use a non-absorbable monofilament suture for skin closure to minimize tissue reaction and ensure long-term wound support. Which of the following sutures should be selected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Nylon Explanation: Nylon is a non-absorbable monofilament suture frequently used for skin closure due to its strength, durability, and minimal tissue reactivity. Types of sutures: Based on the number of strands : Monofilament Polyfilament Single strand of fiber Multiple strands braided together Smooth & strong Easier to handle Decreased chance of bacterial infection Increased risk of infection due to the lodging of bacteria in crevices Knots tied may become loose (6-8 knots) Knots are stable (3-4 knots) E.g.: Prolene Ethilon Nylon E.g.: Silk Linen Polyglycolic acid (Dexon) Polyglactin 910 (Vicryl) (OPTION A): It is an absorbable polyfilament suture. Polydioxanone (PDS) (OPTION B): It is an absorbable monofilament suture. Polyglycolic acid (Dexon) (OPTION B) is an absorbable polyfilament suture. Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, page 106.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man undergoes an open appendectomy, and plain catgut sutures are used for closing the muscle layer. Which of the following statements regarding these sutures is most accurate?

options.A: Non-absorbable and provide long-term tensile strength
options.B: Made from synthetic materials and are highly resistant to enzymatic degradation
options.C: Primarily absorbed by enzymatic proteolysis and has variable tensile strength
options.D: Causes minimal tissue reaction and are preferred for patients with suture allergies

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Primarily absorbed by enzymatic proteolysis, which can lead to variable absorption rates. Explanation: Absorption of catgut is by phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation. Suture Plain Catgut Chromic catgut Frequent uses Superficial vessels ligation Subcutaneous tissues suturing Stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly Same as catgut Contraindications Tissues that heal slowly and require prolonged support. Same as catgut Tissue reaction High (OPTION D ruled out) Moderate Absorption rate Phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 7â€“10 days. (OPTION C) (Option A ruled out) Phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 90 days. Tensile strength retention in vivo Lost within 7â€“10 days Marked patient variability and unpredictable (Option C) (Option A ruled out) Lost within 21â€“28 days Marked patient variability and unpredictable Raw material Collagen derived from the submucosa of sheep small intestine. (OPTION B ruled out) Collagen derived from the submucosa of sheep is tanned with chromium salts to improve handling and resist degradation in tissue. Brown in colour Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page 106.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, during which the surgeon uses Vicryl sutures to close the internal fascial layers. Postoperatively, the patient expresses concern about how long the sutures will remain in her body before being fully absorbed. What is the expected time frame for complete absorption of the Vicryl sutures in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 60 - 90 days Explanation: Complete absorption of vicryl sutures occurs in 60â€“90 days. Vicryl suture (Polyglactin) : Braided, multifilament and absorbable suture. Raw material : Copolymer of lactide and glycolide in a ratio of 90:10, coated with polyglactin and calcium stearate. Tensile strength retention in vivo: 60% remains at 2 weeks 30% remains at 3 weeks Absorption rate: By hydrolysis Complete absorption 60â€“90 days (Option A) Mild tissue reaction Uses: Gut anastomoses, vascular ligatures. â€˜workhorseâ€™ suture in most general surgery. Subcuticular wound closures. Ophthalmic surgery. Used in organs that have a high risk of stone formation: CBD Ureter Bladder 180 days (Option B): Polydioxanone suture is completely absorbed in 180 days. 90 - 120 days (Option C): Polyglycaprone is completely absorbed in 90 - 120 days. 7 - 10 days (Option D): Catgut undergoes enzymatic degradation within 7 to 10 days. Reference: Bailey and Love Short practice of surgery,28th edition, page 106.

questions.question: A 28-year-old male undergoes repair of a laceration on his forearm following a minor accident. The surgeon chooses monocryl for the subcutaneous layer and polyglycolic acid sutures for the deep dermal layer. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding these sutures in this case? Polyglycaparone is preferred over monocryl for subcuticular suturing Monocryl is a polymer of glycolide and caprolactone Polyglycolic acid exhibits highest affinity for adherence to E.coli and staph. aureus Patient is informed that monocryl will be completely absorbed in 180 days
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2 and 3 Explanation: Monocryl suture (Polyglycaprone) : Raw material: Copolymer of glycolite and caprolactone . (Statement 2) Monofilament Absorption rate: 90â€“120 days (Statement 4 ruled out). Tensile strength retention in vivo: 21 days maximum Mild tissue reaction Uses: Subcuticular in skin (most commonly used (Statement 1 ruled out) ), ligation, gastrointestinal, and muscle surgery. Polyglycolic acid suture (DEXON): It is a polymer of glycolic acid Polyfilament suture Absorbed by hydrolysis Maintain sufficient tension over the first 2 weeks Exhibits highest affinity for adherence to E.coli and staph. aureus (Statement 3) . Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/nursing-and-health-professions/polyglycolic-acid-suture https://pu bmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6364858/#:~:text=In%20the%20group%20of%20absorbable,affinity%20toward%20these% 20two%20bacteria . Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page 106. SRB's Manual of Surgery (6th Edition), Page 1154.

questions.question: A 45-year-old female undergoes an abdominal hysterectomy. The surgeon chooses to close the rectus sheath using PDS (polydioxanone) sutures due to their prolonged tensile strength. What is the expected time frame for the complete absorption of the polydioxanone sutures in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 180 days Explanation: Complete absorption of polydioxanone sutures occurs in 180 days. Polydioxanone (PDS): Raw material: Para-dioxanone polymer Monofilament Absorption rate: Complete absorption at 180 days (Option B) Mild tissue reaction Tensile strength retention in vivo: 70% remains at 2 weeks 50% remains at 4 weeks 14% remains at 8 weeks Uses: Instances where slightly longer wound support is required Lowest affinity for adherence to E.coli and staph. aureus 60 - 90 days (Option A): Complete absorption of vicryl sutures occurs in 60â€“90 days (Option A) . 90 - 120 days (Option C): Polyglycaprone is completely absorbed in 90 - 120 days (Option C) . 7 - 10 days (Option D): Catgut undergoes enzymatic degradation within 7 to 10 days (Option D) .

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman with a history of peripheral artery disease presents with critical limb ischemia. She is scheduled for a femoral-popliteal bypass surgery to restore blood flow to her lower extremity. Which suture is preferred for vascular anastomosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Prolene Explanation: Prolene is the least thrombogenic suture material and is often used in vascular surgery . Prolene (Polypropylene) : Raw material: Polymer of propylene Monofilament. Low tissue reaction Tensile strength: Infinite (>1 year) Least thrombogenic suture material Uses: Cardiovascular surgery- vascular anastomosis (Option A) , plastic surgery, rectus sheath, ophthalmic, surgery, general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Disadvantages: Has strong memory- poor knot security Lack of elasticity Silk (Option B): Skin suturing Vicryl (Option C): CBD, ureter and bladder Nylon (Option D): Tendon repair

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Jenkins's rule in the context of abdominal wound closure?

options.A: Use of interrupted sutures with bites 2 cm apart to reduce wound tension.
options.B: Continuous suturing with bites 1 cm apart, avoiding suture locking to create a "spring coil" effect.
options.C: Continuous suturing with locking sutures, with bites placed 1 cm from the wound edge
options.D: Use of mattress sutures to maximize the tension across the wound during healing

questions.explanation: "spring coil" effect. Correct Answer: B) Continuous suturing with bites 1 cm apart, avoiding suture locking to create a "spring coil" effect. Explanation: Jenkins's rule involves continuous suturing with bites that are 1 cm apart and no more than 1 cm from the previous bite, without locking the sutures to allow for a "spring coil" effect that manages wound tension during healing. Jenkins's Rule in Abdominal Wound Closure: Purpose : Optimizes healing and manages wound distension post-midline laparotomies. Technique : Suturing Method : Continuous sutures with bites at least 1 cm apart and no more than 1 cm from the previous bite . (Option B) (Options A & D ruled out) Suture Characteristics : Avoids locking sutures to create a "spring coil" effect , reducing tension during healing. (Option C ruled out) Physiological Basis : Collagen Focus : Targets type I collagen, abundant around 1 cm from the rectus sheath edge. Healing Enhancement : Leverages the natural properties of tissue for improved wound closure. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5991013/

questions.question: Which of the following is the recommended knot for securing the final stitch in a continuous suture technique during surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Aberdeen knot Explanation: Aberdeen knot is specifically used to secure the final stitch in continuous suture techniques. Continuous sutures involve using a single length of suture material to create multiple stitches, and the Aberdeen knot is effective at securing the end of this continuous line of sutures. It provides a secure closure and is particularly useful for finishing a continuous suture , ensuring the stitches remain tight and secure. Common Characteristics of Surgical Knots: Firmly tied : Prevents slippage. Small size : Minimizes foreign material in the body. Preserves circulation : Avoids cutting off blood flow to tissues. Undamaged materials : Ensure suture materials arenâ€™t harmed while tying. Knotting techniques: Granny/ Slip Knots : A knot used to fasten a rope or line around an object, often deemed less dependable than the reef knot. Square/ Reef knot : It is a standard knot with an extra throw for security. (Option A ruled out) Surgeonâ€™s Knot : Extra security, prevents slippage (two-throw knot). (Option C ruled out) Aberdeen Knot : Secures final knot in continuous sutures. (Option B) Buried Knot : Used to secure the ends of absorbable sutures when a subcuticular suture technique is used to close the skin. (Option D ruled out) Monofilament Sutures : Require six throws for secure tying; leave 1â€“2 mm ends to prevent unraveling. Types of Suture Techniques and Knots Suture Technique Description Knot Used Interrupted Sutures Individual stitches, each tied off separately. Tied like standard knots. Continuous Sutures Single length of suture for multiple stitches. Aberdeen knot at the end. (Option B) Mattress Sutures Used to evert or invert wound edges. Tied like interrupted sutures. Tied like standard knots. Subcuticular Sutures Placed under the epidermis for a cosmetic result, using absorbable sutures if needed. Buried knot.

questions.question: Which of the following types of surgical needles is most appropriate for suturing tough or dense tissue such as skin and fascia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Triangular needle Explanation: Triangular needles have cutting edges along all three sides, making them suitable for penetrating tough or dense tissues like skin and fascia. Surgical Needles: General Characteristics Atraumatic (Eyeless) Needles : Commonly used in modern surgery. The suture material is embedded within the shank. Proper Grasping : The needle should be grasped by the needle holder about one-third from the rear to avoid damaging the shank or point. Parts of a Surgical Needle: Shank: The portion held by the needle holder. Body: The main portion that passes through the tissue. Point: The sharp end that penetrates the tissue. Needle Types: Part Shape/Type Function/Usage Body Round-bodied (Option A ruled out) Separates tissue fibers, used in intestinal and cardiovascular surgery Triangular (Option B) Cuts through tough or dense tissue like skin and fascia Point Round Tapered end, general use Conventional Cutting Cutting edge inside curvature Reversed Cutting Cutting edge outside curvature Blunt-ended (Option C ruled out) Minimizes needlestick injuries, used in abdominal wall closure Shape Half-circle Gastrointestinal surgery J-shaped (Option D ruled out) Laparoscopic port site closure Quarter-circle Eye surgery Compound Curvature Oral cavity procedures

questions.question: Identify the type of suturing technique used in the image given below.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Interrupted sutures Explanation: Each stitch is a separate piece of suture material , allowing for individual control over each stitch. Therefore, the suturing technique depicted in the given image is that of interrupted sutures . Suturing Techniques: Technique Image Description Suture Placement Interrupted Sutures (Option A) Needle inserted at 90-degree angle, passed through both sides of wound Distance = tissue thickness, each suture twice as far from edge as previous Continuous Sutures (Option B ruled out) Continuous placement after initial start, with suture appearing diagonal Maintain proper tension, secure end with Aberdeen knot or final suture loop Mattress Sutures (Option C ruled out) Vertical or horizontal, used to align wound edges Passed through both sides, either vertically or horizontally Subcuticular Sutures (Option D ruled out) Aesthetic closure with small bites of tissue, edges easily approximated Absorbable or non-absorbable, secured with collar and bead or buried knot

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient is undergoing ileostomy closure and the surgeon opts for a hand-sewn anastomosis technique. Which of the following accurately describes the single-layer hand-sewn anastomosis technique?

options.A: It includes an inner continuous suture layer and an outer layer of interrupted sutures.
options.B: It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall, except the mucosa.
options.C: It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall.
options.D: It involves placing a purse-string suture on the distal stump and stapling the anastomosis.

questions.explanation: mucosa. Correct Answer: B) It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall, except the mucosa. Explanation: The single-layer hand-sewn anastomosis involves using a continuous suture line that spans through all layers of the bowel wall except the mucosa . This technique is chosen for its simplicity and potentially lower risk of leakage due to fewer suture lines. Hand-Sewn Anastomosis Technique Description Material Used Advantages and Risks Single layer Anastomosis Continuous suture line, all layers except mucosa (Option B) (Option A & C ruled out) Monofilament absorbable Or Vicryl. Quicker procedure Potentially lower risk of leakage Double Layer Anastomosis Inner continuous layer (Albert layer) + outer interrupted sutures (Lembert layer) Inner layer: Vicryl Outer layer: Silk Traditional method with additional support from the outer layer. Risk: Potential for stricture formation. Stapled Anastomosis: Techniques: Method 1: The proximal bowel is opened, and an anvil stem is deployed through the side of the bowel. The bowel is then stapled shut. Method 2: A purse-string suture is placed on the distal stump. The anvil is tied to this suture, and the trocar and anvil are mated through the proximal bowel. (Option D ruled out) Optimal Side Limb Length: 3-6 cm
